Award.AwardTitle: Isotope Studies of Mineral Kinetics Accomplishment-Based Renewal
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will explore the kinetics of element mobility and exchange. Recent technological developments allow isotopic microanalysis of samples a million to a million-million times smaller than previously possible. The mechanisms and rates of chemical reaction and exchange in minerals will be studied with emphasis on zircon and titanite, minerals used to determine the age of geological events. This is the main operating grant of the Geology Stable Isotope Laboratory, which is closely linked to the WiscSIMS Lab at UW, a National Facility for Stable Isotope Geochemistry. The broader impacts include new applications of stable isotope geochemistry, public education, and training at the undergraduate to post-doc level in state-of-the-art analytical techniques. This grant will support two graduate students, and aid two other students plus one post-doctoral fellow in their educations.

The paradigm of chemical equilibrium employing thermodynamics of bulk mineral properties has dominated the study of how rocks form for over 50 years and brought immense progress for understanding the Earth. At the same time, theoretical and experimental studies of mineral grain boundaries and exchange kinetics have demonstrated limitations of the bulk-equilibrium assumption and micron-scale investigations of stable isotope exchange in real rocks have been thwarted by analytical limitations. This project will exploit the combined capabilities two instruments that overcome these limitations: secondary ion mass spectrometry (SIMS) and atom-probe tomography (APT). SIMS measures isotope ratios and trace elements from 1-20 micron diameter spots with excellent accuracy and precision. APT will provide unique information for understanding element and isotope distribution; no other technique provides spatially resolved mass spectrometry and 3-dimension mapping at single-atom scale. When used in context with petrographic observation (visible and electron microscopy) and low-kV electron probe microanalysis, these new techniques promise transformative understanding of exchange rates and reaction kinetics in grain boundaries and nano-domains.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant supported research and publication of a total of 32 peer-reviewed papers in high impact journals and numerous abstracts at national and international meetings. This project has been the main source of external support for 3 PhD students (Turnier, Blum, Quinn) and 1 MS student (Cameron).

We published 3 papers on the emerging field of atom probe tomography (APT) applied to minerals. Blum et al. (2018b) reviewed analysis techniques and proposed "best practices" guidelines to standardize APT data reporting in geological samples.  Blum et al. (2018a) critically evaluated the sensitivity and precision of Pb-isotope ratios measured in zircon by APT. Saxey et al. (2018) reviewed the current state and future promise of APT in geosciences. Blum is preparing papers from his 2019 PhD that apply this rapidly emerging technology to Hadean age zircons from the Jack Hills and from the Moon.

Turnier et al. (2019) calibrated the oxygen isotope fractionation between corundum and calcite in emery deposits that formed by metamorphism of karst-bauxite.  There was no previous direct determination. The values are significantly improved over a value calculated from the modified increment method. For her PhD, Rachelle Turnier is collaborating with the Gemological Institute of America to study the genesis of basalt-associated sapphires.  This includes pressure estimates based on Raman spectra of zircon inclusions in sapphire, and trace element analysis and stable isotope analysis by SIMS. These results have provided new constraints on the genesis of sapphires and provide new criteria for determining the country (district) of origin, which is of interest for responsible sourcing of gems and preventing their use to sponsor terrorism. 

Cameron et al. (2019) analyzed Hadean zircons with concordant U-Pb ages elevated d18O values. SIMS data show that the concordant zircons are not hydrous, and laser Raman shows that the amounts of unannealed radiation damage are uniformly below the level that promotes alteration (1stpercolation point, 2 x 1015a-events/ mg).  These studies disprove the proposal by Pidgeon et al. (2016) that the zircon record of mildly elevated oxygen isotope values in the Hadean results from weathering and hydrous alteration. 

Bonamici et al. (2015) correlated oxygen isotope, U-Pb Geochronology, and textures in zoned titanite crystals from the Carthage-Colton Mylonite Zone, Adirondack Mountains, NY. Rapid cooling (50oC/ Ma) following the thermal peak of the Grenville Orogeny (Ottawan Phase) is demonstrated by preservation of oxygen isotope zoning in titanite.  This is significantly faster than previous estimates based on blocking T of titanite and hornblende, showing that cooling and uplift rates were not linear. These results are interpreted to indicate that the NW Lowlands terrane slid to the NW during gravitational collapse of the mountain belt at ca 1050 Ma.
